intro.heading: Introduction
intro.summary: NASA's Artemis program aims to return humans to the Moon and prepare for Mars exploration, leveraging advancements made since the Apollo program. The plan focuses on achieving a human lunar landing by 2024 while establishing a sustainable lunar presence. Key components include the Space Launch System (SLS) rocket, the Orion spacecraft, and partnerships with commercial and international entities.

figures.caption: Volatiles Investigating Polar Exploration Rover (VIPER) • Orion thermal protection system • Wind tunnel testing and computational analysis for SLS and commercial launch vehicles • Human-autonomous systems • Flight simulators Armstrong Flight Research Center •

Launch System Mock Up arrives at Kennedy for Testing.NASA's Pegasus Barge arrived at the Launch Complex 39 turn basin wharf at Kennedy Space Center in Florida to make its first delivery to Kennedy in support
Artist's rendering of the Power and Propulsion Element and the Habitation and Logistics Outpost (HALO) in lunar orbit.

sections.heading: Early Artemis Missions
sections.summary: Early Artemis missions will utilize the SLS rocket and Orion spacecraft to send humans back to lunar orbit. NASA intends to leverage these missions to test Orion and the Human Landing System (HLS). The Gateway, a critical component for sustainable lunar operations, will be assembled with the Power and Propulsion Element (PPE) and the Habitation and Logistics Outpost (HALO), launching together in 2023. In 2024, Orion will transport the crew to lunar orbit, where they will transfer to a commercially developed lander for surface exploration using the new xEMU spacesuit for about a week.

sections.heading: Sustainable Artemis Missions
sections.summary: Later Artemis missions will involve crew arriving at the Gateway via Orion, enabling research and surface trips. NASA aims for international interoperability and reusable components for long-term lunar sustainability. International partners like CSA, ESA, and JAXA will contribute robotics, habitation modules, and logistics resupply. An Artemis Base Camp at the lunar South Pole will support extended expeditions, including lunar terrain vehicles, pressurized rovers, habitation modules, and in-situ resource utilization systems, essential for long-term lunar exploration and Mars preparation.

sections.heading: Landing Humans on the Moon in 2024
sections.summary: The foundation for returning to the Moon is NASA's deep space transportation system: Orion, SLS, HLS, and Exploration Ground Systems (EGS). In 2021, payloads will be delivered to the Moon via Commercial Lunar Payload Services (CLPS). The Artemis II mission in 2023 will conduct a crewed flight test of SLS and Orion. NASA plans in-space flight testing of the lander system with commercial HLS partners prior to the Artemis III mission in 2024.

sections.heading: Artemis I and Mission Readiness
sections.summary: Artemis I will launch an uncrewed Orion into a lunar distant retrograde orbit, traveling 40,000 miles beyond the Moon to test the SLS rocket and gather engineering data. The high-speed reentry at Mach 32 is a top priority to test the heat shield, which will reach nearly 5,000 degrees Fahrenheit. The mission will deploy 13 CubeSats for scientific investigations and technology demonstrations. Figure 3 shows the Pegasus Barge delivering the Space Launch System rocket core stage pathfinder to Kennedy Space Center for testing.

sections.heading: Artemis II
sections.summary: Artemis II, the first crewed flight of SLS and Orion, will send four astronauts to the lunar environment. The 10-day mission will set a record for human travel beyond the far side of the Moon. Orion will orbit Earth twice before traveling to the Moon, testing life support systems and Deep Space Network (DSN) communication. Crew will exercise and have limited down-time to contact family. Reentry will occur at nearly 25,000 mph, slowing to 20 mph with parachutes for ocean recovery.

sections.heading: Artemis III
sections.summary: Artemis III aims to land the first woman and next man on the Moon by 2024. NASA procured a commercially provided HLS, leaving the door open for proposals that didn't require Gateway.

sections.heading: Extending Lunar Missions and Preparing for Mars

conclusion: The Artemis program is underway, with commercial lunar robotic deliveries planned for 2021. Flight tests will validate rocket and spacecraft performance. NASA will collaborate with commercial partners to develop landers and conduct risk-reducing tests. The program aims to leverage past investments and foster new partnerships to achieve sustainable lunar exploration and prepare for a human mission to Mars. NASA is employing innovative approaches, prioritizing safety, and learning from each milestone.
